pageIntro: Here you will find important words from the blockchain world and the Stellar network. Everything is explained in simple terms.
searchPlaceholder: Search term (z. B. Konto, Account, Muxed)
searchHint: The search finds words and explanations.

blockchain.title: Blockchain
blockchain.short: Gemeinsames digitales Kassenbuch – viele Computer speichern die gleichen Einträge.
blockchain.desc: A blockchain is like a digital ledger. Many computers store the same entries, so no one can secretly alter anything.

wallet.title: Wallet
wallet.short: Digital wallet that manages your keys.
wallet.desc: A wallet is your digital purse. It manages the keys you need to access your account and send transactions. A wallet can be a program, an app, or even just a piece of paper with your private key.

account.title: Account
account.short: A blockchain account can hold assets and send transactions.
account.desc: An account is the place on the blockchain where your assets are held. An account has a public address that begins with G. Multiple wallets can access the same account if they have the correct key.

addressG.title: G-address
addressG.short: The public key (beginnt mit G) of a Stellar account.
addressG.desc: The G address is the main address of a Stellar account. It begins with the letter G. You provide it to others so they can send you something.

publicKey.title: Public key
publicKey.short: Adresse, die du teilen darfst; bei Stellar meist die G‑Adresse.
publicKey.desc: The public key is the address that you are allowed to share. In Stellar, this is the G-address. Others use it to send you money.

privateKey.title: Secret key
privateKey.short: Password to the account – never share.
privateKey.desc: The secret key is your password for the account. Anyone who has this key can move your money. Never share it.

addressFederation.title: Federation address
addressFederation.short: Kurze Adresse wie E‑Mail, zeigt auf eine G‑Adresse.
addressFederation.desc: A federation address looks like an email. Example: name*domain.com. This short address points to a normal G-address. It is easier to remember.

addressMuxed.title: Muxed account
addressMuxed.short: M‑address with additional ID – shares a base account.
addressMuxed.desc: An M-address points to an existing Stellar account but has an additional unique identifier (ID). This allows, for example, the differentiation of multiple people or departments under the same G-address. Technically, the funds still belong to the main account.

multisig.title: Multisignature
multisig.short: Important actions require more than just a signature.
multisig.desc: Multi-Sig stands for multiple signatures. An important action requires more than one key. For example, you and a second key must both agree before something can be sent. This makes theft more difficult.

trustline.title: Trustline
trustline.short: Agreement to hold a token from a specific issuer.
trustline.desc:
A trustline is like saying yes, I accept this token. By doing so, you indicate that your account is ready to hold a specific token from a specific issuer. Without a trustline, you cannot receive this token.

Example: A trustline is specified as CODE:ISSUER. For EURT from the issuer GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y…, it is EURT:GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y…

token.title: Token
token.short: Digital unit – e.g., money, points, or credits.
token.desc: A token is a digital unit on the blockchain. A token can represent money, points, or credit for a service.

asset.title: Asset
asset.short: Tokens on Stellar are always linked to the issuer.
asset.desc: On Stellar, a token is called an asset. An asset is always linked to an issuing account. For example, an account can issue a Euro token. This Euro token is then an asset.

xlm.title: XLM (Stellar Lumens)
xlm.short: Native currency of Stellar for fees and activation.
xlm.desc: XLM is the native currency of Stellar. You need XLM to pay fees and to start a new account.

mainnet.title: Mainnet
mainnet.desc: The real Stellar network with actual value. Transactions are final, and fees are paid in real XLM.

testnet.title: Testnet
testnet.short: Public practice network with no real value.
testnet.desc: A public practice network. Tokens have no real value. Ideal for learning and experimenting without risk.

memo.title: Memo
memo.desc: A memo is a small note that you can send along with a transaction. Often, an exchange requires a specific memo to know to whom the money belongs.

transaction.title: Transaction
transaction.short: Action on the blockchain, e.g., payment or trustline.
transaction.desc: A transaction is an action on the blockchain, such as sending money or establishing a trustline. A transaction is stored permanently once it is confirmed.

fee.title: Fee
fee.desc: The fee is a very small amount that you pay with every transaction. The fee goes to the network. On Stellar, the fees are very small.

ledger.title: Ledger
ledger.short: Chain of confirmed data and account balances.
ledger.desc: The ledger is the chain of all confirmed data. It shows which accounts own how much and which transactions have occurred. Anyone can check the ledger.

horizon.title: Horizon
horizon.short: API‑Dienst, über den Apps mit Stellar sprechen.
horizon.desc: Horizon is the service through which programs communicate with the Stellar blockchain. Our tool queries Horizon to load account balances and transactions.

horizonHistory.title: Horizon History
horizonHistory.short: Describes how far back the transaction history provided by public Horizon servers extends.
horizonHistory.desc: Die von der Stellar Development Foundation betriebenen öffentlichen Horizon-Server (Mainnet und Testnet) stellen nur eine begrenzte Historie zur Verfügung – derzeit ungefähr ein Jahr rückwirkend. Ältere Daten sind über diese kostenlosen Endpunkte nicht mehr abrufbar. Wenn du weiter in die Vergangenheit zurück musst, hast du im Wesentlichen zwei Optionen: (1) du betreibst einen eigenen Horizon-Node mit vollständiger History (inklusive History Archives), oder (2) du nutzt Drittanbieter- bzw. Bezahldienste, die historische Stellar-Daten langfristig speichern und zur Verfügung stellen.

anchor.title: Anchor
anchor.short: Firma, die Fiat‑Geld mit Stellar verbindet.
anchor.desc: An anchor is a company that connects real money, such as euros or dollars, with Stellar. For example, you give the anchor euros and receive a euro token on Stellar in return.

exchange.title: Stock exchange
exchange.short: Place to buy and sell tokens.
exchange.desc: An exchange is a place where you can buy or sell tokens. Many exchanges require a KYC process, meaning identity verification, before you can withdraw money in euros or francs.

dex.title: DEX
dex.short: Decentralized exchange directly on the blockchain.
dex.desc: DEX stands for Decentralized Exchange. Here, people trade directly with each other on the blockchain. There is no single operator. Stellar has a DEX built-in directly.

liquidityPool.title: Liquidity pool
liquidityPool.short: Joint pool with two tokens for immediate exchange.
liquidityPool.desc: A liquidity pool is a shared pool containing two tokens. People deposit both tokens into it. Others can then immediately exchange these tokens. The depositors earn small fees for this service.

balanceClaimable.title: Claimable Balance
balanceClaimable.short: Reserved money that you still need to accept.
balanceClaimable.desc: A claimable balance is money that has already been reserved for you, but you still need to claim it. Only when you accept it does it go into your account.

protocolUpdate.title: Protocol Update
protocolUpdate.desc: A protocol update is an upgrade of the rules in the Stellar network, such as new features or security changes. All nodes in the network must use the same rules.

soroban.title: Soroban
soroban.desc: Soroban is the smart contract system of Stellar. A smart contract is program code on the blockchain. The code can independently verify rules and trigger actions without an intermediary bank.

multiSignature.title: Multisignature (Multi-Signature)
multiSignature.short: Multiple signatures required; weights + threshold determine the release.
multiSignature.desc: In a multi-signature setup, multiple keys must sign before an action becomes valid. Each signer has a weight, and the sum must reach the required threshold. This increases security because a single stolen key is not sufficient.

signer.title: Signatory (Signer)
signer.short: Public key with weight, part of the account configuration.
signer.desc: A signer is a public key that belongs to an account and has a weight. Its signature counts towards the required threshold. Multiple signers can collectively authorize a transaction.

thresholds.title: Thresholds (Thresholds)
thresholds.short: Limits (low/med/high) that determine the required sum of weights.
thresholds.desc: Thresholds define how many weighted signatures are necessary for actions: low for simple operations, med for payments, high for critical changes. The sum of the signers' weights must meet the respective threshold.

masterWeight.title: Master weight (master_weight)
masterWeight.short: Weight of the master key; controls how much the main key counts.
masterWeight.desc: The master weight is the weight of the main key of an account. A high master weight allows the master key to sign many actions alone; a low value requires additional signers.

accountConfig.title: Account configuration (Account Configuration)
accountConfig.short: The interplay of signers and thresholds determines the security of the account.
accountConfig.desc: The account configuration specifies which signers exist with which weights and what thresholds apply. Changes to signers or thresholds are security-critical because they determine how many signatures are required.
